attributes.title: Submission for Develop: Test -
attributes.body:
(In case the doc doesn't open here is a copy of the text)

Felix Ninelives 

November 20, 2019 

 

Petalics Testing 

For this testing we used my dining room table and had my laptop open for the slideshow instructions. It was in the evening and my partner was helping me with this.  

The first feedback I received was about the name and how to pronounce it. I realized a little late that it's not clear and one way of saying it doesn't sound good at all. We had some laughs about that. 

 

Part One - Arranging Magnets 

Subject thinks it would be easier if the magnets we marked as to which side was positive or negative but noted that magnets are too small for that. It takes them about five minutes to set them out and did see how easily they attract to each other. I offer help but they tell me no they are having fun. They mention that the magnets are much stronger than they were expecting for their tiny size. Because the magnets keep clicking back together, they start the first step over twice, similar to what I had to do when I was creating the instructions. I was declined to help again! Test subject is giggling about it and and seems a little amused and surprised. Test subject makes the same circle markings around the magnets as I show in the instructions. Instead of a plus and minus sign they write - 1st and 2nd. 

 

Part Two - Creating Petals 

This part goes very smoothly and they are finished in less than a minute. They mention how easy it is and that it does make a pretty shape that looks like a petal. 

 

Part Three - Attaching Magnets 

Subject notes again how small the magnets are and that it's been some time since they've used super glue. They say, "How does this super glue come out? I guess I just have to keep squeezing. Oh that's probably too much." When they place it on top of the magnet to attach it, they pick up the petal so quickly it does not stick right away. It takes three tries and then it stays. Subject says they're not clear on the next step about how to put extra glue on the magnet stack. When they do follow the step they say, "Oh I see. OK. Should I let it dry before I do the other side?" I mentioned they can just follow the instructions and see what happens. They decide to do the next side like the instructions state and mention how the first magnet did not fall off like they were worried it would. The next 3 petals are made a little faster.  

 

What did you like? 

"I liked the instructions. I wish more things would come with beautiful instructions like this. All the pictures really helped and the layout is nice.  I'm surprised I didn't get any super glue on my fingers so that was good. But I'm glad you brought the acetone just in case I did." 

"I actually liked that the magnets were a little hard to use at first. I like a challenge. Magnets are cool. I want to play with them some more!" 

 

What could be better? 

Laughs. "I think you should change the name! No, I'm kidding. But maybe think about it. (We laugh together). I wish there was a better way the magnets were labeled. Laying them out like that did make sense but I didn't understand why I was doing it until after I did it. Do they have to be this kind?" 

"Is there a way to make the petal pieces a different color first? It would be nice if they had nice colors or designs instead of just brown. I do like the shape, but it would be more interesting if you could play with colors." 

What were you feeling as you made it? 

"I liked helping you with your homework!" (Laughs) "I'm not normally crafty so I was wondering if I was doing it right. If I should be trusted with this! Especially the glue."  

"I really had fun with the magnets. I wish these would dry quicker. I would totally make more of these. I wonder if there's anything else you can make with them." 

"I felt like it was cool to see you make something like this. I really do like the instructions. It was a lot easier than I was expecting. " 

 

Time 

Assembly took 14 minutes after beginning to manipulate the magnets. 

 

Insights  

Consider different magnets or a way to mark magnets. Try to make clearer the meaning or reason they are laid out this way. 

Offer an option to color or paint the petals. Consider whether or not that step would be before or after. 

Think of a different name!

attributes.title: Submission for Deliver: Hypertext Narrative
attributes.body:
From my initial draft I submitted on Studio, I made quite a few changes. The first change came as a result of Tony's suggestion. I added CSS to my story. While I would have enjoyed adding more CSS, for the purpose of highlighting the links by enclosing them in a box, changing the link color to white, and making the text two sizes larger than the body to emphasizes the importance of the links. I also changed the body text's color to black to mimic a typical text found in a word document or book, plain black text, so it is easier to read. I changed the font as well to make it easier for individuals to read than other potential fonts. Lastly, I changed the background color of the story because I felt as if blue represented the idea of wishes well, because blue makes me think of the genie from Aladdin, who grants three wishes.

Per suggestion of Patches, I explored Amber's potential to add depth to her character in her confrontation with Christian. In her confrontation with Christian, Amber wanted to change so she could blossom into a person with better morals and goals. Instead of wanting to walk around in the nicest clothes, Amber would evolve into wanting to leave an impact on the community. I also fleshed out the story via the wish, once again, as suggested by Patches. He also suggested that I branch out additional story points, which I included in the body of text, whether it be giving the reader more context about Amber's relationships with other characters, or more information about what is going on in the environment/scene.

As for changes I wanted to make, and did, I simply finished off the story and made small tweaks that I found to be aesthetically pleasing, such as adding the opening page where the reader can decide if they wish to read the synopsis of the story or if they wish to simply begin the story. I also added/changed all the aspects included above.

attributes.body:
The changes I made to my first draft were imperative to enhance the flow of my story. I took Felix's corrections into consideration and broke up some of the longer passages into two separate nodes. I did this for two passages. I also, created more suspense before Tina's decision to allow Havana to start small with her ideas. I added more dialogue from Tina that indicated her negative thoughts toward Havana's plans. Not only did this create more suspense, but it also made Tina's character traits more consistent. Lastly, I read through the entire story in my head and out loud to fix any grammar/mechanical errors I had made in my draft.

attributes.title: Submission for Deliver: Hypertext Narrative
attributes.body:
# Chains of Command

Intended for a young audience, this hypertext narrative follows a trio of young friends who help the military thwart a diabolical plan in this sci-fi, action-adventure set thirty years in the future. With several twists and turns possible, selecting the first choice in every set of options follows the critical path, and you should be able to complete the mission in under 10 minutes. 

I've added music to my final version to enhance the experience, be it lighthearted or inspirational.  Get set for a fun read.

If you have difficulties unzipping the story file, please try again using one of the more powerful unzipping tools that Dr. O'Toole recommended below:

- For Mac:  https://theunarchiver.com/
- For Windows:  https://www.7-zip.org/

attributes.title: Submission for Deliver: Feedback
attributes.body:
For Tom:

First off, I'm already enjoying the title of your story, If a Tree Falls. It sounds very promising and is suspenseful in itself. So far, I've gathered the two main characters Brody and Calresta. I am curious to read more information on John, I'm guessing he has passed, possibly tragically. The description of playing with your brother and the air feeling like "razor blades" was quite descriptive. I had a good picture in my mind of what that would be like. 

Brody seems to be on a mission to stop illegal logging in Siberia. I'm wondering if it's a government entity that he's a part of some sort of futuristic global environmental police force, which I'm sure we could use. These pods sound impressive with a good opportunity for cool future-tech. I find myself picturing them something like escape pods from Star Trek, but if they are to be shared, they must be bigger. I'm curious about the safe zone and why it needs to be safe in the first place. Who else is in Siberia with them? 

The incoming message on Brody's communicator (Or maybe it's a phone but I'm picturing a cool futuristic communicator) really got me engaged. He sounds like an eco-hero along with Calresta. Who are the other people on the mission besides Calresta and Brody? Who is their guide? 

The idea of eco-wood sounds interesting and I hope the story has more info on that. Is it why they have stopped all logging?  

I think this story could have a large young adult to adult audience. I could see it being a good topic for today's young adults who need some real hope about their future but also good for adults who need hope as too.  

I didn't really feel like I had enough time to write the story I was imagining. Professor O'Toole suggested I focus on a "first chapter" approach if that helps you at all with the time management. Good luck with the final draft.  

For Devon:

I love the choose your own adventure style of this story! There a plenty of characters to follow and their personalities come through. Quade seems very serious and going through some internal motivations about leadership. It's clear that this adventure is his chance to prove his leadership abilities to himself or discover something else about himself. Your descriptions of Claire and Leo as well as their dialogue adds to their development of their friendship. Gemma, George, and Quade's parents help develop Quade's character as well as being "foil characters" to define Quade's personality. Blackbeard is a great mysterious stranger who joins in the adventure. His prosthetics make the reader wonder about his past. 

I enjoyed the third person Point of View and felt it was appropriate for this kind of story. 

The secret Navy base reminds me of the "evil corporation" character trope like the one I'm developing in my story. The laser guns instantly make it futuristic. The seal pup is a classic animal trope used in stories that gives it a "awe" factor. It did feel a little out of place with the seriousness of the story a bit for me. It didn't quite fit in for me. 

San Diego is a great setting for a military like story. I lived there for a few years and your imagery brought back some fine memories, especially of Coronado bridge. 

You created interest by getting the reader invested in Quade's internal struggles, with the idea of an evil or mysterious organization and the death of a stranger. Having the reader choose the next steps also created more interest. 

The story made me feel interested about what happens next. I found myself wanting to know even more about these futuristic above water cities. I wasn't sure how these above water cities were connected to the adventure of the group but maybe that would happen in a following chapter.  

I think the best audience for this story would be people currently or formerly in the military. I felt a little "left out" with some of the terminology I didn't understand.  

You met all the requirements of the project and even added styles to it. I like the font you have much better than the default one of twine. The only things I can think of that may make the story better is explaining some of the navy lingo and finding a way to fit the seal pup into the tone of the story. Overall, it's a great start to a story and I was left wanting to learn more about this secret navy base and about Quade's personal journey.  

For Selkirk:

I'm intrigued about your idea for a story. Since you can hypothetically do anything in VR, your story could go in numerous directions. If you're having trouble figuring out which way to go, the tvtropes website has a lot of great ideas to help you get it going. Sometimes, having a big idea is difficult to turn into something small, at least it was for me.  

I am reminded of Ready Player One. I haven't read the book, but I saw the movie with my 14 year old son (who did read the book). There was a lot of back and forth between the real world and the VR world, the VR world being fantastical and infinite and the real world being rather drab and dystopian. While the movie itself was a little cheesy for me, it had some great concepts about how things that happen in VR can change the world. If you haven't seen it and you like science fiction, video games, and 80s references, then it could be a fun way to generate ideas for your story! I certainly didn't hate it, but I did hear the book was better (typical!).  

The snarky president seems like he could make a good villain for your story. I'm really hoping the pro gamer will be female! It would be great to generate some gamer friends for sidekicks. Maybe they could live stream everything on Twitch! So many possibilities! For the setting, you can have some be real world and others be VR. 

The audience could truly be anyone, but geeks and gamers would be at the top of the list. Good luck with the rest of your story!

attributes.title: Submission for Deliver: Feedback
attributes.body:
Wally,

I believe you have developed a very brilliant concept in your story and I commend you for that.

I believe your use of CSS truly makes the story experience more enjoyable and leaves a greater impact on the reader. I do, however, have a few pieces of feedback about your story:
- You may want to add more details to parts of your story, such as what does the tour consist of, why does Mr. Berrymore want to take the tour, why is it so expensive, etc. -
- Again, just adding more detail in your story to make your story line clearer would be amazing, such as expanding on Mr. Berrymore's thought process at the end would be very insightful about more of his character's personality and his dynamic. -
- I believe parts of your story can be slightly confusing, so if you just going back through your story and make sure it flows easily, that should solve the issue. -
- Perhaps add some sort of a back button since I imagine you eliminated the pre-programmed one with your customized CSS. If not, it is definitely not a big deal. -
Overall, fantastic job! There were only a few minor things but the story and its' concept completely made up for it.

Felix,

I know I am not in your group, but I accidentally reviewed your story for feedback and then realized I am not in your group, but I thought I would provide you with some feedback because it could be helpful?

Your story was very enjoyable to read! You included lots of beautiful imagery and a plentiful amount of detail, which I much appreciated. The amount of content you provided on each page was also fantastic because it was not overwhelming but was not underwhelming either.

The only feedback I have for your story is to simply finish it off. I noticed there was a slide or two that just needed to be finished and that was all I had notes on. Once you finish those pages you will have one fantastic story!

When you write those pages, it would be nice if you added a backstory on why ADevon's father created the technology he had and how it works. I believe this could allow for a fantastic opportunity to add some conflict/drama/dynamic into your story, which could be beneficial.

Once more, fantastic job!

Patches,

I simply cannot put into words how phenomenal your story truly is! I have absolutely no feedback for your story because it is already perfect in my opinion. I would just recommend going back and rereading your story for spelling, grammar, capitalization, and punctuation, but that is it.

Well done on your piece, it is fantastic! Your piece has a wonderful story line, dynamic characters, and resolved conflict which makes it incredibly interesting.

Bravo!

attributes.title: Submission for Deliver: Feedback
attributes.body:
**Feedback for Jeanette Ninelives:**

Hello Jeanette,

I found your action/adventure story very engaging with the descriptive character development in the main character, Penny "Hercock".  As a person that was different than everyone else in school, I found Penny's character very easy to relate to.  Your supporting characters Jesse (supportive friend), Professor West (mentor), and Ms. Clark all help to develop the story and define Penelope's character.

The rising action works very well as a build-up to a possible encounter with the mysterious texter, making me want to know who or what this person is.  Also, who could be in the white Corolla that is following our young Penny? It reminded me a bit of the scene in the Matrix with Neo (chosen one trope) receiving a cell phone, then getting directions from Morpheus that were, at the time, incomprehensible.  How do you really know to trust the person hacking your phone (or the ultra-intelligent AI imbedded in your new phone)?  The inclusion of nanotechnology to create HVDC is an interesting concept, and if realized, would definitely make a positive change for electricity and the future as we know it. 

From reading your story and plot elements, it appears that your story will take place mostly in present day, with the outcomes leading to a renewable energy grid in place by 2049.  I am looking forward to seeing how your story continues, are you planning on writing any of the story in the future of 2049?

The third-person POV your story is written in was easy enough to follow, while still keeping me engaged.  As far as the choice for Doritos, I would have to agree with the store clerk, Cool Ranch!  

For me, I found that I didn't have enough time to get my draft fully written this week, so I decided to create a rough outline that gave different options with different outcomes.  Although not required, have you considered branching your story out in Twine with the linking capabilities to different story arcs or options for the reader to select?  I was always a fan of the choose your own adventure books when I was younger (dating myself here), and being able to create a story in a way like this I found extremely challenging, but fun.

I don't know that I would make any drastic changes to the  story you have completed so far, but I did find myself wanting to click on the text link before reading the passage in its entirety.  By having links within the text, it seemed to interrupt the story for me.  Other than a few spelling typos, I wouldn't personally change any of the content in the draft you have created.

 I feel you are in process of creating a cliffhanger, that has me waiting for you to complete the story so I can realize the outcome.  I almost felt myself wanting to add the next node to the story.  Creating an open story in which the reader creates the next passage could be an interesting option as well.

-Tom

**Feedback for Devon Rex:**

Hello Devon,

Your story Chains of Command is very interesting, and I feel it lends itself to a swashbuckler action/adventure narrative with all of the Navy jargon, secret Navy bases, the prosthetic leg-wearing character "Black Beard"/Ryder (classic pirate trope), the floating cities, house boats, and the seal pup character "Goldie".

I enjoyed how you portrayed the main character, Quade studying for the history quiz to explain how the future came to be. It is a different way to show, not tell how the future has developed, but explaining it in a manner that makes sense to the story. I know that you explained in the history lesson about AI integration that has created things such as smart energy, automation, gene editing and such, but other than the communication device for Goldie, I didn't see much of a positive view of the future with irreversible global-warming destroying/transforming much of the coastline. Although I understand the benefit, I feel that gene-mapping to determine how someone will best learn and benefit society seems to lend itself to a system that would limit an individual's creative potential.

The third-person POV your story is written in, is very easy to read while keeping me engaged. The intersecting paths of your story gives the reader interesting options to learn more about Quade's friends Claire and Leo. I also enjoyed the interaction with Quade's mother and "the twins". I never had younger siblings, but the interaction between Quade, Gemma, and George reminds me a lot of my daughter and my son.
I did have a bit of difficulty remembering which path I chose in your story. I also had to reload the story from the beginning any time I wanted to go back and reread a previous page or try a different path, which was a little frustrating. If you were to create a link back to decision nodes, it may be a bit easier to try alternate decisions throughout the story.

Changing the background to white and text to black was a more familiar appearance than the white text and black background default in Twine. I don't know that the change necessarily reflects the tone of the story, but I certainly appreciate your effort in customizing your layout. The connection with the navy and gold text hyperlinks to the school colors was a subtle detail that I enjoyed.

It appears that you have changed the body fonts to Lucida Console in the coding. There are some different options you may want to check out at google fonts https://fonts.google.com There is some alternate fonts from the basic web safe fonts that may lend themselves to your story better. I haven't tried it with Twine yet, but here is instructions for the Sugarcube platform that you used: https://twinery.org/cookbook/googlefonts/sugarcube/sugarcube_googlefonts...

Overall, I really enjoyed your story. Some readers may have some difficulty understanding a lot of the military terms and ranks used, which may limit your audience. I found myself wanting to know more about Quade's backstory, and learning what caused him to not get elected for class president. The lack of being a leader seemed to have a real profound effect on Quade, ultimately pushing him harder to become the leader he longs to be. A branch node could possibly explain this backstory, or you could leave the mystery to the reader's creative mind as you have currently. Your story is very-well written, and I found myself deeply submersed (intentional pun) in the story and characters you have created. I look forward to seeing how you wrap things up for the final project.

-Tom

**Feedback for Selkirk Rex:**

Hello Selkirk,

Your democracy run by VR is a concept that I find rather intriguing. Allowing anyone that feels they are up to the challenge to compete for presidency or make changes to policy would certainly change the outlook of the future. Presently, VR has expanded to many aspects outside of the gaming industry, so I certainly believe this is a plausible outcome. Last month, I photographed on a story for our Public Affairs Office about a VR program we are using to teach painters new skills without having to waste material resources. You can check it out here if you would like: https://www.tobyhanna.army.mil/News/Article-Display/Article/1951875/virt...

I think you would be pleasantly surprised by how much of a positive impact video-gaming has had within the tech-industry, the military, and much more. Although there are many negative stories associated with language, sexual exploitation, and violence in video games, there are also many positives that have come from it as well. Flight simulators have been used for quite some time to train pilots in different aircraft, without risking injury or damaging aircraft. Simulators are able to run countless scenarios that wouldn't be feasible in a real-world environment.

I believe that you could evolve your story into a very detailed VR scenario where pro-gamers could create government policies and test them in the virtual environment before they are implemented. I feel there could be a much bigger picture than just winning at a video game, given the capabilities we have already begun to see in the development of AI, especially video game AI, I see no reason that this couldn't be implemented in the future for determining policies and to see who would be the best candidates for a particular position in office.

Your character of the president sets a tone of arrogance, that could fit in to a cruel executive villain character trope. The confident pro gamer could be considered the hero as he/she is preparing to battle the great villain of tyranny. I look forward to seeing how you develop your story and characters, and I feel you have a good foundation to expand on.

-Tom

**Peer Feedback posted on October 21st, 2019.**
Other group members (Lykoi Van Sternberg and Chloe Caturday) Hypertext Narrative Drafts not posted so I could not peer review.
For group member Toby Mouser:
Hi Toby! I enjoyed reading what you had and I think there's a lot of potential for your story, as the premise of it sounds really action packed and fascinating. I would recommend making it a little longer however and adding a few more links/pages. Some other recommendations I have would be: Grammar- on the first page I noticed his was spelled as hos, obviously this was just a typo but I thought I'd point it out just in case it got skipped over. On the second page you had crys out but since you used past tense throughout your whole story it would be cried out and then remember to put the comma and quotation marks after. Also on the second page there was another typo where you put no instead of now. I think adding a little more background and detail to the setting at the beginning of your story would be helpful, too. I think it just jumps right into dialogue and action and might be confusing to the reader. Best of luck

attributes.body:
**Comments for: Felix Ninelives (posted 10/21/2019)**

Hi Felix,

Really enjoyed your Action-Adventure-Suspense narrative with a young protagonist.  This is my favorite genre to read and watch.  Penny is a highly intelligent and likable character with supportive friends, family, and teachers.  I appreciated the story line with its buildup of suspense and tension over the mysterious phone calls/text messages and implication of "bad guys" on the walk home.  I also enjoyed the inclusion of some techy jargon, and I can see areas for possible fun side adventures like when choosing Cool Ranch or Nacho Cheese chips.  Your use of the 3rd person point of view made the narrative easy to read and flowed nicely, and your inclusion of descriptive words really enriched the scenes and made it a pleasure to read.  

Here are my ideas that might help improve your narrative and take it to the next level:

*	To fit the entire critical path arc into 10 minutes is a very difficult task and, if you'd ask me, is much too short for great story development.  I truly loved your story so much that I'd gladly spend the time it takes to get to the end, but for the assignment's 10 minute limit, you may need to create and split off some of the world and character building background into side adventure arcs.

*	While submitting my first draft, I discovered that my line breaks after paragraphs disappeared like yours.  My work-around was to input manual line breaks using < b r  / > or < b r >.  (Note that I have had to add extra spaces in this bullet point because Studio reads the commands as code, not a part of my sentence.)  Check out https://www.w3schools.com/TAGS/tag_br.asp for more info.  I placed the break in the whitespace between paragraphs, though it did make the break lines more pronounced (further apart) than I would prefer.  There may be a better way but, without taking an HTML class, this is what I gained from Google Search and it seemed to work for my purposes.

*	To easily find grammar and spelling problems, you might consider cutting and pasting your sections into Word or a site like Grammarly.com.

*	Lastly, if you're interested in adding color, images, or sound, here's a helpful website I found that I'd like to share with you: http://www.adamhammond.com/twineguide/.  He provides lengthy walk-through videos but shows his coding underneath the videos in case you want to skip them.

Congrats on a great, positive story with characters of depth.  I look forward to reading your final version.

Devon

**Comments for: Tom Cat (posted 10/21/2019)**

Hi Tom,

Your Action-Adventure-Suspense narrative has some wonderful plot twists and different endings, making it a fun narrative to read.  I especially appreciated the ability to "go back" and to "start over" which helped me to fully enjoy all the possibilities very easily.  I believe that Brody has great potential as an interesting, hero protagonist and Claresta will make for his perfect partner by the end.  I'm guessing that their opposite natures and skills will make them stronger heroes when combined.  I also love how Claresta is the one that saves Brody, probably by outsmarting the "bad guys".  The inclusion of some future techy jargon like Neurolink lends an enjoyable Sci-Fi element, too.

Here are my ideas that might help improve your narrative and take it to the next level:

*	Would love to see some dialogue between Brody and Claresta.  I imagine that their interactions would be full of snark and healthy competition.  Being both "good guys", I would think that they'll find compromises and learn to work really well together.  

*	When possible, add descriptive words and scene settings that will engage the reader and help them to become immersed in that world.

*	While submitting my first draft, I discovered that my line breaks after paragraphs disappeared like yours.  My work-around was to input manual line breaks using < b r  / > or < b r >.  (Note that I have had to add extra spaces in this bullet point because Studio reads the commands as code, not a part of my sentence.)  Check out https://www.w3schools.com/TAGS/tag_br.asp for more info.  I placed the break in the whitespace between paragraphs, though it did make the break lines more pronounced (further apart) than I would prefer.  There may be a better way but, without taking an HTML class, this is what I gained from Google Search and it seemed to work for my purposes.

*	To easily find grammar and spelling problems, you might consider cutting and pasting your sections into Word or a site like Grammarly.com.

*	Lastly, absolutely loved the picture of the two boys running in the field (one of your pics?), but if you're interested in adding some color or a bit of sound, here's a helpful website I found that I'd like to share with you: http://www.adamhammond.com/twineguide/.  He provides lengthy walk-through videos but shows his coding underneath the videos in case you want to skip them.

I truly look forward to reading your final version.  This is one of my favorite narrative genres, and I like the direction your multiple story lines/endings are headed.  

Devon

**Comments for: Selkirk Rex (posted 10/21/2019)**

Hi Ari,

I really like your plot premise.  It should lend itself well to a psychological thriller with lots of action and suspense, delving into virtual reality Sci-Fi elements and real life psychology patterns.

Here are my ideas that might help improve your narrative and take it to the next level:

*	When possible, add descriptive words and scene settings that will engage the reader and help them to become immersed in that world.  For character buildup, try dialogues that exude their personalities and think of language or jargon that they might use.

*	To easily find grammar and spelling problems, you might consider cutting and pasting your sections into Word or a site like Grammarly.com.

*	While submitting my first draft, I discovered that my line breaks after paragraphs disappeared.  If you suffer the same frustrating difficulty, my work-around was to input manual line breaks using < b r  / > or < b r >.  (Note that I have had to add extra spaces in this bullet point because Studio reads the commands as code, not a part of my sentence.)  Check out https://www.w3schools.com/TAGS/tag_br.asp for more info.  I placed the break in the whitespace between paragraphs, though it did make the break lines more pronounced (further apart) than I would prefer.  There may be a better way but, without taking an HTML class, this is what I gained from Google Search and it seemed to work for my purposes.

*	If you're interested in adding color, images, or sound, here's a helpful website I found that I'd like to share with you: http://www.adamhammond.com/twineguide/.  He provides lengthy walk-through videos but shows his coding underneath the videos in case you want to skip them.

This is a creative plot, one that I'd definitely choose to read or watch, and I look forward to reading your final version.  

Devon

attributes.body:
Chapter 1:

It is a normal day in City Green. Where the traffic is rushed and the streets are filled with day to day people. It is a Friday morning, Second period at Leafy Green HighSchool.The late bell rings with everyone ready for class to begin, expect one. In comes a bright yellow hair kids slowly sneaking to the back of the class. "You're late Mr.Blade!" says the teacher with quite an annoyed look on her face. All eye turn to the kid with the yellow hair giggling and laughing at his exposure. 

Blade: "Sorry Mrs.P I woke up late."  
Mrs.P: "Oh, so you were working all night on your science project then?
Blade: "Ahh...of course!"
Mrs.P: "Then why don't you go first then!"

The children laughed as they watched Blade walk his way to the first. 

Mrs.P: "You may begin."
Blade:"I did my project on the ecosystem."

Blade begins to clear his throat.

Blade: "For the last 50 years the ecosystem as experienced an increase of pollution of the years from harmful pollution and over extracted natural resources. This hazard is affecting the air we breathe, the water we drink and the state of our over all environment. But with health and eco-friendly practices we can make a change before it is too late."
Classmate: "Too late for what exactly we've been doing fine so far?"
Eloho: *rolls her eyes*
Blade: "Well if we don't do something soon The Fec-"
*Eloho quickly interrupts*
Eloho: "The Fog of pollution will effect our water and turn us into three eye mutants!"
Classmate: "Yeah right?!"
Eloho: "It's true, have you ever heard of the Populus people?"
Classmate: "No."
Eloho: "They too thought the same way you did until it was too late. Now they have hands for feet and feet for hands because of the toxic air that poisoned their body."
Blade realized Eloho's recover up after he almost spoke of the evil villain The Fecaltor. 

Chapter 2:

After a long day of school the day is finally over. By day Eloho, Tommie and Blade are known as everyday teenager in the world. But, at night they are busy saving the world from the evil Fecal-ator who plans to ruin the ecosystem with pollution and toxins. On this night the group plans to stop Fceal-ator once and for all at their headquarters.

Eloho: "Blade! You gotta have more self control people can't know the whole truth just yet." 
Blade:" Yeah, Im sorry about that guys."
Tommie and Eloho: "It's alright."
Tommie: "What's your plan guys, the other day I noticed less birds in the park then usual and not a squirrel insight." 
Blade: "Really?! Already! I thought we would have more time!"
Eloho: "Fudge! We really need to finish this before it's too late. Blade did you come up with any new designs for new gadgets?"
Blade: "Yeah, I show you."

*Meanwhile at the City Green's landfill *
A man with the head of a toilet and the smell of a unflushed toilet awakes from his garbage piled bed.  

*To be continued*

attributes.body:
# Chains of Command

Thirty years in the future, a trio of students help the military thwart a diabolical plan in this action-adventure, hypertext narrative.  With several twists and turns possible, selecting the first choice in every set of options follows the critical path, and you should be able to complete the mission in under 10 minutes.  

If you would enjoy some background information about events that occurred in the story's thirty preceding years or about the school the trio attend, select the choices to study for the history quiz or to give a campus tour, respectively.  You may find some light comedy in other story arcs so check those out if you're interested.

Note that this is a resubmission of my previous draft which, after being uploaded to Studio, had a frustrating disappearance of line spacing occurring after paragraphs.  Using < br / >,  I have created hard line breaks which will hopefully resolve this problem of white space.

I hope you enjoy the story.

attributes.body:
BIONA

'Good morning',[[ Zaiyasia]], says to herself in the mirror. She glanced out her window and was immediately saddened because of the destruction she saw. It was early September and Zaiyasia used to love the change in seasons from summer to fall when she was a child. That no longer existed. It was 110 degrees outside at 7 a.m. in the morning in New York City. 

Zaiyasia was originally from Sau Paulo, Brazil. She moved to New York City when she was 16 years old. Her mother had gotten a job as a scientist and her father died when she was young. She always wanted to study the earth and loved watching her mother work as a biochemist at a company called BIONA. "Zai, one day you will grow up and change the world." her mother used to say. Unfortunately, her mother passed away a year after Zaiyasia graduated with honors in Biochanetic's. She then went on to get her masters in Geology. Zaiyasia had an amazing reputation on paper, however she was a women and times changed from when women were respected in the science community. Not only was she a women who wanted to change the world and reverse climate change, she was a women of color. 

Ziayasia worked for the same company her mother worked for, Biona. Biona is a chemical research company that was supposed to revert climate change but instead caused great damage to the earth and the human race. Through the invention of super storms, Biona was able to give humans super powers. By the time it was too late, Biona had affected more than half of the human race and this super storm overtook any human that had been unknowingly given super powers. 

(The Story will continue!!)

I fixed an error I had noticed myself that had occurred on the bus menu. After completing the setup of the bus schedule, you are left on a screen that tells you what days your child will be taking the school bus. From there, if you were to click on the bus icon again, it would send you to the beginning bus menu which is left blank with no bus schedule set. My other change is to the look of the beginning Bus Schedule menu. I added a feature to the bus schedule menu that will let you know there is no schedule set, and how to set the schedule from there. Before, it only had the days on the screen, it was very empty and possibly confusing as to figure out what to do next on the screen.

Upon doing this assignment, I found that I really enjoy coming up with ideas for apps that could potentially help people with rituals they could have day to day. I was a bit behind so I didn't get to update my project more than what I have, but for what I have now from what I originally submitted I'm quite happy with my progress.

I ended up using PS to create artboards, then I exported the Artboards into a folder in order to transport them into the Invision app to create what I have now. I can't think of other things to add, so I decided to submit this as a final. It was a really great learning experience and I got to experiment with Photoshop and got the handle on that as an application which I'm happy with.

attributes.title: Submission for Deliver: Final Prototype
attributes.body: As I did not receive any further comments/suggestions/feedback since I uploaded my latest iteration of my app, I made small changes that I felt were appropriate. In my timer feature, I added the ability to end the timer while in use and if the user desires, they can reset the timer. This can be accessed once the user sets a timer, the countdown will appear once they confirm how long they want the timer to be set for. Underneath the time left on the timer is a x and the word remove. By clicking this button, the user ends their current timer and are sent back to the timer's front page. From there, the user can go home if they wish, to the menu bar, or they can set another timer. Another change I made was adding the ability for users to add a rank to recipes from the pre-existing recipes front page. After the user selects to view pre-existing recipes, they can view the recipes they have saved, or they can rank the recipes in their library. By ranking these recipes, the rank individual users' rank will contribute to the overall ranking of recipes by all the members within the meeting. Under the rank recipes tab, the user can view how each recipe ranks that members of the family have ranked. The most popular recipe will be ranked as number one and any recipes that are tied will rank as the same number. This tool assists the selected primary grocery shopper in having a better understanding of what all the members in the family wish to have on the meal plan.

attributes.body:
RITUAL PROJECT
Deliver: Change Log

 After receiving positive feedback from my group peer (Tony Tigre) on the changes made during the iteration process, I decided to self-reflect as well as further investigate the changes that my peers were making in their projects. Taking some time to think about the different concepts I could lend to the prototype, something that I noticed in other projects became a reoccurring pattern. My prototype is based around connecting with like-minds in similar situations, but just like any other social-based network this comes with a certain air of caution for the user. 

With this in mind, I included the use of an overlay much like a 'popup' alert that is used in the inbox/messages screen of the prototype. This is set off if the user is attempting to open a message from someone not currently on their friend's list, and as a reminder to never give out personal information. In previous versions of this prototype, this feature was never included, and it was with the aid of my peers and their projects that I was able to realize that there could be an instance when a user would need an alert and reminder like this one.

attributes.body:
After much effort and research I could still not get the loading screen to function correctly.

For the final prototype of this app, I added two more drop down menus. One which is functional and delivers three different screens for the tracking option and another which gives the user options for displaying means by most popular, most recent, or older memes categorized as "classic." There is also a separate process for finding a new sidekick, a working link to the "Journals for Sale" screen, and the option to see the Track from the home page. I also changed the home page screen so the top sections wouldn't seem like a button but more like a message.  

I corrected some wording and reformatted much of the text to make it appear less busy and more centered.  

There is also an option to flag a sidekick's comments in case they are inappropriate. The little flag will change to black when tapped. 

The Support Page now has links that work to a Contact Us page with a submission form, an FAQ page that explains how the app works, a Code of Conduct that outlines the guidelines of safety and appropriateness, as well as a Privacy pages which lays out the apps policies around sharing information and support of anonymity. In the support pages, swiping right will bring you back to the main support page.

# The Buddy System

This is a prototype for an app that connects people who share common life experiences and interests.  For many people, meeting and making new friends can be hard.  This app could bring people together and help them gain more pleasure from life.

**Background**: My Dad, at age 87, enjoys socializing with friends but, sadly, many of his dearest friends have passed away over the years and it's been difficult filling those losses.  With this app, he could be matched with people of similar interests and backgrounds.  

My Storyboard describes the ritual he might follow if he were to find a source of friendships based on mutual hobbies, backgrounds, and locations.  In the Storyboard scenario, I focus on his favorite hobby of building model gliders and how that might proceed after successfully using The Buddy System.  Currently, without the aid of the app, he creates model gliders and takes them to the park for test flights all by himself, but as the Storyboard tells with the help of The Buddy System, he could contact a matched buddy (Frame #2) to share the experience of test flights at the park, changing it from a solo activity into an engaging, interactive one that is so key to a senior's well-being.

**Concept and Use**: The app would require a user to create a profile that would include information like location, occupation(s), hobbies, and activities.  Using an algorithm like ones used for matching couples, users will be alerted of a "buddy match".  Each user will be able to click on the potential buddy's profile and decide if they want to "Buddy Up" (accept) or "No Thanks" (decline) the match.  The potential buddy will do the same process and, if both parties agree to "Buddy Up", they are added to the user's buddy list.  If users already have friends using the app, they can perform a "Buddy Search" and complete the "Buddy Up" process that way.  For quick and easy reference, users would have the option to consolidate their best buds in a "Besties" list, including the handful of buddies they might contact frequently.

**Safety/Privacy Considerations**: Because there is an element of risk and anxiety connected with strangers, cautions of "Stranger Danger" and tips on making and keeping new friendships will be included.  As a safety precaution and to protect privacy, the internal messaging capabilities would allow a user to contact others without revealing their personal information like email, phone number, or address, and users would have a mechanism to block unwanted strangers and report any "Red Flag" like issues.  Making new friends should be a positive experience.  Unfortunately, some may try to take advantage or abuse the privilege.

**Marketing Strategy**: Initially, I would focus my marketing strategy on developing relationships with senior assisted living homes and senior housing communities, national organizations like AARP and the Alzheimer's Association, city and local senior wellness programs or centers, and medical professionals specializing in gerontology.

The Buddy System's slogan is "...because life is too short.  Let's live it having fun!"  Aging seniors are not the only group that could benefit from The Buddy System.  This app could be spun-off to include other groups that find themselves cut off from social interaction like new moms and dads, caregivers, and more.

attributes.title: Submission for Develop: Prototype
attributes.body:
Prototype 

Description: This app is designed to aid a person who is on the go in their search for a new job. The design is simple for the common user and effective for employers as well. 

Ritual:  How might we assist someone find a new job, who has limited time, who has trouble navigating already existing job applications? In order to solve this issue, I believe there should be an easier way for job seekers to communicate with potential employers. Websites like Indeed have skewed results due to sponsoring. Indeed can be ineffective due to the user having to go out and search for the job themselves, whereas my app, Jobber, brings the option to you.

The app: My app is called Jobber. The user fills out a brief profile of themselves that employers will see. They set distance preferences, a pay range, full/part-time/internship, hard and soft skills, and selecting interest categories. When making an account, there is a section for employers where they can search for potential candidates as well. The app then shows you a brief description of each job, which has the position title, pay, distance away from home and how long it will take you to get there with traffic. When the user clicks on the distance module, it brings the directions to the location of the job in Google maps. Similar to Tinder, the user will swipe right or swipe left depending on whether or not they are interested. If you swipe right, it will automatically add that job to your "liked jobs" section. After reading the brief description, there is an option to "select more" where it gives you a detailed description of the average day there called "what would my day look like". There is an option to send your resume/cover letter, and if the employer wishes to include contact information to follow-up. There is also a section that helps you form your resume and cover letter. Whereas Indeed sponsors certain employers so that their jobs are listed at the top, my app will include various adds (Men's Warehouse, Staples, etc.) in order to make a profit, but the job listings that pop up are solely based on the preferences set by the user.

attributes.title: Submission for Deliver: Final Prototype
attributes.body: I took Cornish and Devon's feedback about the security issues into consideration. To address this, I added an alert. If the user taps an event invitation from someone whom they are not currently friends with, they are alerted by a red overlay, for the golf invitation in this case. The overlay recommends they use caution but also suggests bringing a friend with them to the event for extra piece of mind. This provides added security but also could also promote further activity between users. From the overlay, the user can choose to return to the search, or continue to event detail page.

attributes.title: Submission for Daily Design Journal: Report In
attributes.body:
All out of the 14 objects. My top items are dog leash, ring doorbell, apple mouse, and dog ball. All of those items are simply formed, heavily reliable, functional, and a key element of daily life. Start with a dog leash which is every dog owner must-have. It protects a dog from unpredictable situations and takes control where the loved one go in front of you. Ring doorbell securely managed my house and keeps me updated with surroundings events and rings my phone directly. I was able to respond to the door effectively. And my other essence tool for every day is apple mouse where I can navigating my computer to work, study, and entertainment. Speaking of beneficial item for dog entertainment is a squeezable tennis ball and goggle-eyes bait for my dog to keep occupied and entertaining while I able to do something else at same time.

Outside of my selection of top items. Apple watch did the most dependable when I am not with my phone and it notified me something important like how did the ring doorbell do. I use it a lot for timer or alarm for my everyday needs. Apple watch can be easily overlooked from its importance but it runs the key factors of everyday use. Without it, I will be out of track from the schedule or timetable subjects and out of reach notifications. I do not take it as granted because it earned an essential tool for our everyday life necessities.

Of the 14 objects I sketched, I woul dhave to say my favorites are my PS4, Xbox, 3DS and my PC. I realized when sketching things, drawing anything with a curve or as a circle made me cringe on levels I didn't think were possible until now. Mainly it was only that way due to how unstead my hand is when it comes to drawing curved lines. Hence my favorite drawings being the ones with more of a linear approach.

The insulin pen is a very important part of my life. I chose to draw it since it is a part of my daily living, and if I were to not have it, I would probably die, so there is that. I think of all the objects, the one I take for granted I feel like is my phone. It's something I've grown used to having around, especially when the world started transitioning to smart phones. I remember my old Nokia, that thing was solid. I'm so used to having my phone that on the occasion that I DO forget it I feel almost lost and extremely bored. Every other item I find special in their own ways.

attributes.title: Submission for Develop: Test and Iterate
attributes.body:
I did not receive any feedback from peers, however I was able to show my first prototype to my husband and he gave me some feedback. I added some additional information to my original prototype. The first addition was the page that users would click on to view their universal studios tickets and access their cards for park admissions. The second addition was the page for the meal plans and the express pass for the users who purchased the express passes. Adding these features will help my peers better understand what my app will be used for! 

My app idea is based off of a family vacation I recently went on to Universal Studios and islands of adventure. While traveling through the park we used a paper map which most of the days got lost or wrinkled and was illegible. Ultimately it was difficult to navigate through the park and recalling which rides we road versus the rides we didn't. Along with the location of where the rides we hadn't rode yet were located. Another pain point was all the cards we had to keep track of when inside the park. When you have a family of 5 it becomes a little stressful carrying 15 different cards for 3 specific things. We had our meal cards, express passes for each park that we had to take out at every ride, our key cards, and a special stroller rental card for our 3 year old. Needless to say, it was A LOT to keep track of. This gave me the idea of creating an augmented reality app or an interactive hand held map that was connected to your smart phone or electronic device. It would allow you to coordinate with the park and show you which rides you've been on and which you have not. It would direct you to dining options, allow you to have everything located on your map. From your admissions tickets, dining cards, express passes, etc.

attributes.body: My favorite objects from my design journal are probably the alarm clock, pack of gum, Samsung Galaxy Note 10 Plus, and the car key fob. These are also some of the most essential things that contribute to my day-to-day life. My alarm clock is probably my most useful object in here. I've been terrible at waking up the alarm I set on my phone and this is the only thing I've found to be able to wake me up. I use it everyday and it never fails me. I feel like I take most of these objects for granted. The only exceptions would probably be my key fob for my car and my phone. I'm very grateful to have these objects and know I could lose them at the snap of a finger.

From the 14 objects that I sketched, my favorites are the mini backpack, my wallet, laptop, and soccer cleat. My backpack, wallet, and laptop are things that I use in my everyday life. The soccer cleat is one of my favorites because I played soccer my entire childhood and teenage years up until I started college. I kept my favorite pair of soccer cleats from when I played in high school as a memory. 
My phone and laptop are 2 objects that I would say play a huge role in my life. I use my laptop every day to get my homework done and other work needed to be done. I use my phone every day to get in contact with people that are important to me. If I did not have either of these objects, I wouldn't be able to do any homework or get in touch with anyone. 
Sometimes I take having a phone for granted a lot. I don't always remember that cell phones can do so much nowadays, basically everything a computer can do. I usually take the camera on my phone for granted forgetting to take pictures all the time. Sometimes I am logging into my computer to check my email, when I can just do it right on my phone.

attributes.title: Submission for Daily Design Journal: Report In
attributes.body:
From the 14 daily journal entries I would have to pick the cone as being a favorite because they always seem to find me. Driving to work, home, store, etc., these cones are everywhere. I even use them at work to block off areas that I need to get to. Pennsylvania always being under construction is like having the same nightmare every night for the next five years, when I drive past the same road that has been under construction for  five years. I am also choosing the Xbox controller as a favorite, only because the working of the controller over the past few years have really made a difference for gaming. PlayStation has always stuck with the same design and seems to be getting smaller, in my opinion and the grip is just tedious after a while of playing. Xbox went from these huge controllers that seemed to be wasted space, to the compact one I drew that is issued today. The grip and feel fit better to 80% of gamers because it is what we look for when gaming for long periods of time. I also wanted to include the bird piece of art that we have on my wall in our living room. I have always noticed it there, but since I drew it, I have noticed a lot of the theme we have in our living room, and how each bird figure/painting/piece of art has a unique way of showing itself and to stand out among-st each other in their own personal way.

It's obvious as to what object I will select for the next question, the Xbox controller. I am a very active/competitive gamer. You're considered a gamer if you play 2-3 hours everyday few days. That is nothing, I play everyday and sometimes that might be all I do when I play on my days off. I always set aside time to be able to play. I used to play competitively for money and rank, and basically bragging rights, but now that I am older, I play for fun, which some games offer competitive play, these techniques of me being able to unwind with something I love and have a passion for have a way of keeping themselves in my life. Whether I play a game that is 20 years old this year and still holds a ton of value to a newly released game/expansion. The role it plays in my life is a way for me to unwind. My brain works so fast most of the time and I find it hard to relax, it makes me jittery and nervous or causes anxiety for no reason really. Having adhd is not a fun thing to deal with on a daily basis. So playing something that requires me to use every single working part mathematically, to coordination, to focused awareness, which there is a lot of different things that are involved, bring me to be able to relax and actually get tired at night. This helps me calm down and stop running laps in my mind and sets it to a semi sleep mode that eventually results in my ability to be able to sleep at night. If I did not have these things anymore, or the gaming, trust me the solid only answer is I will find a way to buy, or acquire them again. That is why I keep old systems and games around to buying new ones. It's always an ever changing market in gaming. 

Sometimes on a general note, I will take a lot of things/surrounding objects in my life for granted. Only because you eventually become busy, and or are pulled in different directions in life and are left with the fact of those things sitting and not being used. I own a lot of guitars, at the time I was heavily influenced by music but this led to over the years the equipment just wasting away and sitting. From time to time I play but have sold off a lot of the musical equipment because of not having the time or creating the time to do it. Although, a lot of these objects in my life hold significant value, you just get older find new hobbies, or get too busy with life and other responsibilities that things are left behind and or are not used anymore. With the every changing technology we have today, a lot of musical equipment is being replaced with plugins and programmable instruments that you do not even really need an instrumentalist anymore just someone to understand the concept of music in order to create it.

attributes.body: Through the feedback from my peers, I was able to add a few things to my app to enhance it. A couple of my peers suggested that by adding background checks it would be able to increase the feeling of safety and draw more consumers. When you get to the booking page in the app, you will be able to click to view the sitters near you. That will bring you to a page showing the top 4 local sitters in your area, along with how far they are from you. This will be the page where you can request a background check. Parents will be able to explore all the local sitters profiles, which provide their name, email, DOB, level of experience, preferred age range, and if they own their own vehicle. After viewing all the different profiles that you want, you will be able to request a background check by entering the sitter's name and email. This will then send a link to the sitter's email that brings them directly to a background check page to be completed and sent back to the parent.

We'll be submitting most of our work throughout the semester to this Studio space, which is designed to approximate the traditional art studio. In the studio, it is common for students to see each others' work in progress and to hear and overhear feedback from peers and the instructors. To approximate this experience, your work in this environment will be open - that is, your peers will be able to see your deliverables as you work through projects. And you'll be able to comment on and receive feedback from peers on each assignment, though only a few project steps will require feedback or critique.  

For this exercise, we'll simply practice submitting to the Studio. Please select an image or graphic to represent you and introduce you to your peers in the course. Select the "Submit Assignment" below, and upload your image to the Studio.

Changes to prototype 

 
In this version of LaughTracks I decided to redo all of it in Adobe Illustrator for the sake of making changes later. This wasn't regarding any feedback I received, but what I realized was going to make the process so much easier for me since I am already familiar with the program. 

Per the feedback, I added a home page that would give the users a clear base to work from, so they didn't get "lost" in the app. I included this option in the drop-down menu.  I included the set-up process where the user creates a profile, finds a sidekick, and then chooses the best day and time to perform the weekly check-in. The home page also gives the user the option to select a new sidekick. For now, I linked it back to the page during set up where you select a sidekick but eventually, I want it to have a unique process. 

I added all three questions for the user to answer as well as three questions that are inputted. Those questions would are used for the "My Track" feature. For "My Track" there is now a clearer concept of how the graph would appear although it is still not functional.  

I did add some images of memes just to make it clearer within the prototype that the memes would be predetermined by the app with topics that related to goals. 

I was unable to include a hotspot where you could either swipe left to continue or right to go back. It didn't seem to be an option on InVision. I was also still unable to create the loading screen which contains the logo.

attributes.title: Submission for Develop: Test and Iterate
attributes.body:
I made the following changes to my Meal Planning Meeting app: I added the ability to view and add and remove friends/family members on the app and I added a feature to rank recipes that the primary grocery shopper added. The biggest change I made to the app is that all members have access to all features in the app, not just the primary grocery shopper. The family should decide and discuss outside of the app who the primary grocery is going to be for the week or if they even want to assign the role of a primary grocery shopper to any individual.

To elaborate on the changes I made, I listened to Wally's suggestion to add a friends list where users have the ability to add or remove friends as well as view their current friends. Specifically, there was initially only a feature for adding members to the meal planning meeting, but once the user clicks on the Friends/Add Members to Meeting feature, the page now lists two options: add members to meeting or accessing the users' friends list. If the user choose the friends list, they have the ability to view their friends list and to add/remove friends from the list. If the user chooses to add friends, they can add friends by username, email address, phone number, or by social media accounts. If the user chooses to remove friends from their list, they can simply click the 'x' located next to their name.

I also added a feature for users to rank recipes. This suggestion was provided by Patches. The feature can be viewed from the recipes page. Users can add recipes into the ranking feature through the pre-existing recipes page. Users can use the ranking feature to drag their favorite recipes to the top and their least favorite to the bottom of the page. The page will automatically number the ranked recipes according to how all of the members of the party rank the recipes. This allows of the family members to have an understanding of which recipes are the most popular among the rest of their family members.

Lastly, I changed the entire outlook of the app as a result of Tortie's comment. She is right when she stated her view about the app's users' usability while navigating the app. The primary shopper may vary among the household and may not be one constant figure, so limiting and restricting features considering the users' role is unfair. In my household, we only had one primary grocery shopper, so this thought did not cross my mind. Now, all users have access to the same content. There is not specific content that is for family members and for the primary anymore but rather all of the features are available to all users.

attributes.title: Submission for Daily Design Journal: Report In
attributes.body:
Out of the 14 objects my favorites include my sunglasses, standing fan, wallet, make-up brush, and decorative hooks. I've never regretted any of these purchases for a moment and find that I get a lot of use out of all of them. 

-I love my sunglasses because they fit my face nicely, only costed my 17 dollars at target, have a fun blue tint that makes me happy to look through, and fit on top of my head without falling off. 
-My standing fan was something I've needed for awhile. After much research I chose this one from Amazon. It was affordable, pretty quiet, and easy to put together for myself. It also comes with a remote control which is handy when I'm in bed. We've had a quite a few heat waves this summer and my life has been much more comfortable with it in my life. 
-My wallet is very simple. It has a lovely blush color which is one of my favorites to wear and "goes" with almost everything I wear. My phone and lip balm fit in there nicely along with my cards and cash. It has a strap I can wrap around my wrist. I like to travel light and avoid big purses so this one makes me really happy. The fact that I've been using it for over two years is pretty amazing!
-This make up brush is one of the best I've had. The fact that it is detractable makes it perfect for travels and I love the way it blends in my foundation as well as powders.
-The decorative hooks were one of the first items I bought for my apartment after my separation. I have a thing for arrows, love the Ninelives gold color, and needed a place for my necklaces. It always makes me happy to look at it. 

While not on my list of favorites my desk chair plays the most important role in my life out of all these objects. When I initially moved into my own apartment I didn't even have a desk. When I decided to go back to school last year, it was clear I was going to need a desktop computer and a real place to do my work besides my bed! At first, I thought I could use the exercise ball as a place to sit but soon learned that wouldn't work for long periods of time. I now spend several hours at my desk a day and have a comfortable place to sit. If I didn't have it anymore I would need to go back to the exercise ball which was pretty uncomfortable. Or I would need to spend money on another chair which is not something I have a lot of at the moment. 

I really appreciate most of these objects, with the exception those that are at my workplace. Spending money is a big decision and it brings me a lot of satisfaction to know I have spent my money well. In addition, some objects hold sentimental value, such as the decorative hooks, that remind me of important points or aspects of my life. The arrow itself is a metaphor for moving forward and aiming ahead as well as my love of necklaces and organization. The backpack represents my perseverance and busy life. My red stapler reminds me of the movie Office Space and always makes me giggle when I use it. The mechanical eraser reminds me of drawing and the tiny details I like to make with pencil.

# The Buddy System

This is a prototype for an app that connects people who share common life experiences and interests.  For many people, meeting and making new friends can be hard.  This app could bring people together and help them gain more pleasure from life.

**Background**: My Dad, at age 87, enjoys socializing with friends but, sadly, many of his dearest friends have passed away over the years and it's been difficult filling those losses.  With this app, he could be matched with people of similar interests and backgrounds.  

My Storyboard describes the ritual he might follow if he were to find a source of friendships based on mutual hobbies, backgrounds, and locations.  In the Storyboard scenario, I focus on his favorite hobby of building model gliders and how that might proceed after successfully using The Buddy System.  Currently, without the aid of the app, he creates model gliders and takes them to the park for test flights all by himself, but as the Storyboard tells with the help of The Buddy System, he could contact a matched buddy (Frame #2) to share the experience of test flights at the park, changing it from a solo activity into an engaging, interactive one that is so key to a senior's well-being.

**Concept and Use**: The app would require a user to create a profile that would include information like location, occupation(s), hobbies, and activities.  Using an algorithm like ones used for matching couples, users will be alerted of a "buddy match".  Each user will be able to click on the potential buddy's profile and decide if they want to "Buddy Up" (accept) or "No Thanks" (decline) the match.  The potential buddy will do the same process and, if both parties agree to "Buddy Up", they are added to the user's buddy list.  If users already have friends using the app, they can perform a "Buddy Search" and complete the "Buddy Up" process that way.  For quick and easy reference, users would have the option to consolidate their best buds in a "Besties" list, including the handful of buddies they might contact frequently.

**Safety/Privacy Considerations**: Because there is an element of risk and anxiety connected with strangers, cautions of "Stranger Danger" and tips on making and keeping new friendships will be included.  As a safety precaution, the internal messaging capabilities would allow a user to contact others without revealing their personal information like email, phone number, or address, and users would have a mechanism to block unwanted strangers and report any "Red Flag" like issues.  Making new friends should be a positive experience.  Unfortunately, some may try to take advantage or abuse the privilege.

**Marketing Strategy**: Initially, I would focus my marketing strategy on developing relationships with senior assisted living homes and senior housing communities, national organizations like AARP and the Alzheimer's Association, city and local senior wellness programs or centers, and medical professionals specializing in gerontology.

The Buddy System's slogan is "...because life is too short.  Let's live it having fun!"  Aging seniors are not the only group that could benefit from The Buddy System.  This app could be spun-off to include other groups that find themselves cut off from social interaction like new moms and dads, caregivers, and more.

attributes.title: Submission for Daily Design Journal: Report In
attributes.body:
The fourteen objects I drew include: a purse; a duck stuffed animal; a pitcher; an outdoor stand; a Scrub Daddy; a dog bowl; a felt pumpkin; an engagement ring; a unicorn stuffed animal; a small screwdriver set; a pair of diamond earrings; a whisk; a mixing bowl; and a cat food storage container.

Of these fourteen objects, my favorite include: the duck stuffed animal; the Scrub Daddy; the dog bowl; the engagement ring; the diamond earrings; the whisk; and the mixing bowl. These are my favorite because my husband and I won the duck stuffed animal at a fair and once we rescued our cat, we gave the stuffed animal to our cat so he had something about his size to snuggle up to. Given that, the stuffed animal holds a special place in my heart. The Scrub Daddy is an staple in my kitchen. I use it every single day and would preach to the world how fantastic of an invention it is! No other kitchen sponge remotely compares! I am obsessed with the dog bowl because it was the first Rae Dunn piece I ever bought! Not to mention we bought it as a bowl for our rescued dog, so it is perfect for him! My engagement ring holds a near and dear place in my heart beyond its' symbolism of our commitment to each other. It has great meaning to my husband because he ring was originally was his grandfather's and he proposed to his grandmother with that very ring. The diamond earrings mean a great ordeal to me because my father made it a priority that I had a nice set of earrings for my wedding. It meant the world to me that he wanted me to have something so nice for a day that meant so much. I love my whisk because it is from the brand Tasty. Tasty provides a colorful array of options of affordable kitchen utensils and I believe they are an easy way to brighten up the kitchen. Lastly, the mixing bowl is one of my favorites because I love to bake! My mixing bowl gets used constantly between how often my husband and I cook and bake. I had another large mixing bowl made of glass that I heavily relied on before this my mother gifted me this one but another bowl in the glass set shattered in the dishwasher so now I rely more on the Pyrex bowl.

The one object I choose is my purse. My purse is an everyday use in my day-to-day life. If I did not have my purse anymore, I would have to carry around my wallet and any other essentials I may need in a different bag or in my hands, which would be a major inconvenience. A purse is vital for most women because it provides the ability to transport any items individuals may need throughout their day/their outing. For me, if I do not have my purse flung around my shoulder or anything else I have with me firmly gripped in my hands, I would just leave it somewhere and not remember about it for awhile. So, if I did not have my purse in general, I would just leave all of my personal belongings everywhere and lose all of my stuff within minutes, hours, or days. To put it simply, I would be incredibly lost without my purse.

While I believe I personally cherish the small things in life; however, I also believe I still take those small things for granted. I appreciate each and every one of these items for personal and varying reasons, but do not always acknowledge that. An example of this would be my engagement ring. I wear it every time I go to leave the house with my wedding band; however, every time I put it on my ring finger, I do not always think of the reasons why this ring is significant and special. It holds great meaning but I do not always acknowledge that as I slip it on my finger. Some days, I just put it on and go, while others I take the time to reflect its' beauty, depth, and symbolism. I take for granted the commitment I wear upon my finger simply because I do not recognize its' greatness every time I wear it. Every time I put it on I should think to myself how great the love is that I share with my husband and what a beautiful commitment we have to each other. That would be a way to appreciate the small things that are special without taking them for granted.
