attributes.title: Submission for Daily Design Journal: Report In
attributes.body:
Tom Cat
Dr. Gregory O'Toole
DMD 100: Section 002
26 September 2019

**Daily Design Journal**

**Prompt**

1.	From the 14 objects that you sketched, which are your favorite objects? Why?
Of the 14 objects that I have sketched, I have three objects that are my favorite; the Nikon D750 camera, my Macbook Pro, and my 3R80 knee.  The reason I chose the Nikon D750, is that it is one of the tools that I use to do my job every day.  I take thousands of pictures every week, and the camera has grown to be an extension of myself.  The camera allows for custom configurations to suit my own shooting style, so I know how the camera will react in most situations.  I chose the Macbook Pro because it is a tool that I use for many different functions.  It allows me to complete the majority of my schoolwork, edit photos, create videos, develop graphics, and it can run pretty much any software that I have chosen to use, while still being portable enough to take with me wherever I go.  I use my laptop on photoshoots, and it can be tethered to my camera so clients are able to view final products while still on location.  Finally, there are few objects that can completely change your life and radically change how you are able to experience the world.  The 3R80 knee has opened up a world of opportunities to me.  Having a waterproof prosthetic knee, that is not tethered to a power source, that has functionality superior to most microprocessor knees is an astounding feat.  I have been able to hike, kayak, and travel to locations that have never before been possible.
2.	Select one object from your list. What role does this object play in your life? What would be the result if you did not have it anymore?
The 3R80 knee's role in my life is that it gives me the ability to walk, run, and experience life in a way that I never have been able to do before.  It is a prosthetic knee that has felt more like an extension of my own body than any other, and I feel that I have near complete control of the prosthesis because of it. 
If I did not have the 3R80 knee anymore, I would still be able to walk with my other prosthetic knees, but it would be extremely difficult to do my job as a photographer.  I would no longer be able to run, walk in the ocean, play in the water with my children and my dogs, stand in the shower, and walking up steps would be much more difficult.
3.	Do you generally take these objects for granted or are they special?
These objects have become so integrated into my daily activities, that they feel more like an extension of me.  I take these objects for granted more than I probably realize.  If any of these objects were to cease to exist, it would create a radical change in my daily life.

attributes.title: Submission for Develop: Test and Iterate
attributes.body:
After receiving the feedback from my peer, I had decided to take their advice. Changes were made to the original Home Screen, in order to accommodate a more welcoming, and positive reinforced attitude, as well as ease of access. I had realized that though the aesthetics were simple, this would leave a user to click around a great deal of times in order to find what they were looking for, which could be complicated if they aren't sure to begin with. 

In order to address this, I brought the buttons I had included throughout the entire app to the forefront to provide a user with all the options and leaving nothing hidden. This also simplified the buttons at the bottom of the app, which were edited to fit the new style throughout the remaining screens. 

I also included features that I had not to think to include, with the aid of certain options being brought to my attention in the feedback provided. This included a designated help section that could provide the user with an abundance of information and outside help, so not to limit them to the app as well as understand that the app is not a professional, simply a tool to be used. 

Other buttons included on the homepage that are new to the prototype would be the forum button, which would provide more directly the use of a previous spoken about feature for users to network at their own pace. The added coping button would lead to different resources that the user would be able to apply to their situation and give them options on different coping methods given their particular situation. The guidance button is also new, but previously mentioned, and thought it would be beneficial to include different means of meditation and other exercises both mental and physical that could also provide different coping mechanisms. 

The wide variety would hopefully cover the majority of situations that any one user could find themselves in, without limiting the experience and usability of the app.

attributes.title: Submission for Develop: Prototype
attributes.body:
My app idea is based off of a family vacation I recently went on to Universal Studios and islands of adventure. 
While traveling through the park we used a paper map which most of the days got lost or wrinkled and was illegible. Ultimately it was difficult to navigate through the park and recalling which rides we road versus the rides we didn't. Along with the location of where the rides we hadn't rode yet were located. Another pain point was all the cards we had to keep track of when inside the park. When you have a family of 5 it becomes a little stressful carrying 15 different cards for 3 specific things. We had our meal cards, express passes for each park that we had to take out at every ride, our key cards, and a special stroller rental card for our 3 year old. Needless to say, it was A LOT to keep track of. 
This gave me the idea of creating an augmented reality app or an interactive hand held map that was connected to your smart phone or electronic device. It would allow you to coordinate with the park and show you which rides you've been on and which you have not. It would direct you to dining options, allow you to have everything located on your map. From your admissions tickets, dining cards, express passes, etc.

attributes.body:
Prototype

Description: This app is designed to help members in a neighborhood or community find a good local babysitter for their children through the help of other members in the community.

Ritual: How might we get families and friends in the community to share babysitting resources? I believe that getting babysitter suggestions from friends in the community would make people feel that their children are safe. If people are consistent with posting flyers around the neighborhood about babysitter recommendations it would be a huge help in the community and make the process of finding a babysitter a lot easier.

The app: My app is called Absolute BestCare. After a member creates their account/profile, the app will become an easy way for a parent to find a local babysitter. When making an account the user puts in their address and the app automatically pins your location to others around you with the same app, including babysitters and parents. The app is designed with a home button where you can add a number of kids and start a booking (if you already have a babysitter in mind), or navigate to the network button to get connected with members in the community. When you are networking, you are able to schedule a meeting with app members in the community for more insight on certain sitters or schedule a meeting with a local sitter right away. There is also just a page of flyers that will be posted from community members of local sitters they have had experience with. You can also view community recommendations that will be posted from members and will be able to see a rating of each sitter. In another button, you are able to start messages with whomever you want, as a faster way to get in touch.

attributes.title: Submission for Daily Design Journal: Report In
attributes.body:
Of the 14 objects, I would choose the water bottle (entry 1), the bluetooth headphones (entry 4), the retractable dog leash (entry 9), and the guitar effects pedal (entry 12) as my favorites. It's simple, functional, doesn't spill, and won't break. The headphones are my main audio source at home, doing chores, and when running. I use them to listen to music, podcasts, and audiobooks. They were fairly inexpensive and have stood up to a lot of wear and tear; a good value. I like the retractable dog leash because of its dependability. Its hand brake system is very sturdy and has thankfully prevented my dog from running into traffic on a few occasions. It is also more versatile than a standard leash, so more slack can be given when walking on a short leash isn't necessary. Another favorite object of mine is the guitar effects pedal. The simple one button/one knob layout makes it very easy to use and adjust. I also like the bright orange color.
The water bottle stands out to me because it is with me everywhere I go as well as around the house. I take it to the gym, to work, and on trips in the car. I carry it with me habitually and feel that something is missing if I happen to leave it behind. I have had bottles very similar to it in the past and have replaced them immediately when they have been lost or stolen. It is very much a part of my everyday routine. 
Some of the objects from the journal are special to me, especially the favorites I listed above. The dog leash in particular carries memories of dog walks and hikes. I know how much my dog loves them, and in a way the leash signifies the bond I have with her. Some of the other objects are absolutely taken for granted. The fidget spinner for example has no use to me at all and I sometimes forget the humidifier/diffuser serves a purpose other than being an oddly-shaped bit of plastic. Most of the other objects either have everyday functionality or some sort of memory tied to them, in that way, I do not take them for granted.

attributes.title: Submission for Develop: Prototype
attributes.body:
[Invision App](https://invis.io/JDU1BM6ZNQ6)

Inspiration: 
My friend Ron suffers from anxiety and depression. His overwhelming anxiety limits him from meeting new people, visiting crowded places, and mostly, seeking help for his depression. In the past, when he had sought medical help, he would end up seeing a physician assistant, nurse, or someone that he ultimately did not feel comfortable speaking to. He has now begun to self-medicate without any doctor consultation and has been on a downward spiral that has led to an alcohol dependency. His negative experiences and fear of crowded doctor's offices continue to prevent him from seeking help. 

How Might We Statement:
How might we overcome the low expectations and negative past experiences of a person with a pessimistic view about seeking the help they need for treatment, when they want to feel better? 

The Ritual:
The ritual is to light a lantern each morning, and to extinguish the lantern each evening. The symbolism of the lantern being lit, is that no matter how dark your day may become, there is always a light shining to help you find your way.  

The App: 
Lantern 

Prototype Description:
This is a prototype for an app that creates a ritual that is intended to break Ron's routine of negativity and alienating himself from others. The goal of the app is to connect with others to share positive statements with each other. For the first use of the app, the user lights the lantern and views a positive message to get started. At the end of the day, the user creates a short video making a positive statement that is captured within the app. The positive statement could be about themselves, their day, or an event that has passed. After creating the statement, the user must extinguish the lamp to end their day. When you wake up in the morning, the lantern is relit, then the positive message is replayed to start your day. Each statement is stored by date, and by completing "lantern lightings", the user unlocks new features within the app (ie: create a positive statement for seven days in a row, and you can unlock a locate friends feature, creating incentive for making positive statements).
My friend Ron is extremely self-conscious about his appearance, and was apprehensive about hearing his own voice during our interview recording. I have decided to include within the app avatars and different voices that can be used to encourage more creativity and fun within the app. This also allows greater anonymity between users when sharing positive statements with each other.  As more "lantern lightings" are completed, more avatars, customizations, and voices become available.

attributes.title: Submission for Daily Design Journal: Report In
attributes.body:
Looking through my Daily Journal Entries, I've narrowed my favorites down to three.  Each entry appeals to a different aspect within me: fashionable, sentimental, and hopeful.  First, my eyeglasses combine utilitarian necessity with pleasing fashion sense.  Without my glasses, I cannot see clearly, and without their cat-eyed shape and illuminating, burgundy color, my face and complexion might not look as pretty.  Then there are my home keys and car fob entwined with my sons' college logos, the University of Colorado and the University of Southern California.  Without my keys, I wouldn't be able to start my car or enter my home; nor would I be able to express my immense pride in my sons' accomplishments.  Finally, my bud vase that sits on my work desk.  Without this sign of cheer and hope, my mental state while studying would seriously lack inspiration and encouragement.

But the one object that I could not live without is my laptop, as I'm sure many would agree.  It's a necessary staple like food, water, and air.  I require it for schoolwork, communicating with friends and family, and enjoying hobbies.  I grew up in the 70s and 80s before computers were available to the masses.  Our first family computer was a Commodore 64, which most people have never even heard of, but it revolutionized my high school term papers from a clunky and permanent typewriter to an easily revisable printer.  My first "portable" computer was a Macintosh SE in the early 90s and provided by my auditing firm.  It was so heavy and bulky that taking it to a client's workplace required a luggage dolly.  Back then, if we wanted to stay in touch with friends, we'd have to use stationary and a 15-cent stamp; there was no email.  Further, without my laptop, I couldn't easily experience Netflix or Hulu when I'm bored.  For all the concerns about computers dis-socializing the younger generation, we need them in today's industrialized, tech-heavy world.  

Of the 14 objects I journaled, I can honestly say that I take for granted 9 or 10 of them.  From personal hygiene to food handling, from lamp light to cooling fans, many objects are just there every day, day-in and day-out.  Like cavemen became used to fire, I've become used to modern conveniences born from electricity, societal norms, and commercialism.  I don't "see" these objects and express my gratitude that they're here but, if they were gone tomorrow, I'd sure miss my toothbrush, soap, lamp, fan, silverware, coffee mug and more.

attributes.title: Submission for Develop: Prototype
attributes.body: This is a prototype for an app I created called TRUcareer. The idea came about after a conversation I had with a close friend of mine about how she wanted to do what her dream career is, which is hair. She went to college for social work and currently works for the state. Yet, she talked about how miserable she is at work and how draining it is. She described how she would love to pursue her dream but she is scared because of all the time invested into becoming a social worker, as well as not knowing enough about how to be successful as a hairstylist. Thats where the idea for TRUcareer came into play. It is an app that you sign into and create a profile, showing contact info, credentials, profile picture, etc... Then you search for the right career by typing in keywords to your dream job. Then, and official job title appears, based of your keyword search. So if you search "hair" then hairstylist/barber will appear as final search results. then you can click and connect with other people who are in that same industry and have already transitioned from their previous career; being able to have 1 on 1 conversations with each other. Message boards is another search result for your career of choice where it is an interactive forum to ask questions and receive answers from everyone. lastly is the Info boards, listing job opportunities, further education, and assisting opportunities.

attributes.title: Submission for Develop: Prototype
attributes.body: This is a prototype for an app that will help you make healthier choices whenever you're on the go or find yourself in a time constraint. Say for example you're running late to a meeting and you notice it is about noon or after your regular lunch time. As you are rushing to your meeting you happen to rush by the cafeteria at work, you open the app to select a time frame around your same time and the app gives you suggestions on what to grab for a healthier choice. These choices can range from full meals, to things that might be better for a quick on the go snack. This is great way  to make healthier choices, as to selecting the time and snack to meal, the app is not made to track the food you eat, just to help suggest a better alternative to your daily lifestyle. This is great support, because the apps offered today, loosing weight and starving yourself with these weight loss apps are just a bummer, you can still eat whenever you feel or need, but the ability to have better choices instead of doritos, or mcdonalds, could be an apple, or veggie chili. With more work to the prototype, I will eventually add the ability to be able to choice between a snack and a meal, and also a notifications setting to remind you that you're not alone. For example, Hey!!!(notification on the phone) Did you drink enough water today? and or, Did you eat a healthy choice? If not let us help to help you find better nutritional values today!!

attributes.body:
**Prototype Description:**
This is a prototype for an app that will help alleviate the pressure felt by busy and working parents from trying to complete daily household chores for their families every day. This app will assist in getting those pesky tasks done in a short amount of time by setting a timer with a pre-set time (Ex. 30 Minutes) based on the area chosen. It will give you specific tips that will help get your chore done along with an example list of tasks sorted by their importance. Once the timer is up, the user will have the ability to connect with other users of the app through a discussion forum. Here, the user has the chance to chat with others about what and how they do things in their own home and even share special tricks they might use. If the user chooses not to comment on the forum, they will have the ability to start another chore or opt-out (done). When done, the user will receive a daily summary of what chores they have completed that day and previous days the app was used. The user will then be rewarded a set amount of points (one point every minute)  based on the time they put in on their chore(s) that day. Once the user reaches 1,000 points, they will receive a coupon for a cleaning product or cleaning service.

attributes.title: Submission for Develop: Prototype
attributes.body:
This is a prototype for an app to help people stay on track towards their goals utilizing humor, ease of use, connection with another, and a weekly check in. I came up with this idea while interviewing my brother who has played music for years but feels he needs to improve but doesn't feel like he's taking enough action towards the goal. The prototype walks the use through the ritual but does not include prompts to build a profile, as time did not allow. I find that depression or regret about not working towards a goal ends up preventing people from continuing to try. Humor can help ease the depression and, combined with a ritual that feel very easy, will generate more positivity and focus without seeming overwhelming. Connecting with others also generates good feelings and empathy which helps the user "get out of themselves" for a moment which will also generate more positivity. The journal is a part of the ritual that is intended to be a little more serious than the rest of the experience. Writing things down with pen and paper will help the process feel more real and give the user a resource to look back on and have a way to track progress, besides just using the app. The app stores favorite memes, a chart from each check in, a profile page, and a support page with links to app support and FAQ. 

  

The ritual entails choosing a day of the week and time of day where the user has about 10 minutes to sit down with a journal. First they begin with some friendly words from the app and a silly meme related to setting goals from an anonymous "sidekick." They then answer three questions in their journal about their week, with a minimum of three minutes writing. The user then chooses one answer to send to their sidekick, after which they read their sidekick's submission. Lastly, they get to choose a meme to send to their sidekick and have the option to "favorite" memes and keep on a screen in the app. The app encourages the user to end the ritual and put their phone down, although an option still exists to redo the exercise or review favorite memes. 

  

Side note: I have noticed that, despite rechecking inVision multiple times, some bugs exist. It will not accept my loading screen (which has the logo for the app) and some hotspots are not working, such as swiping.

attributes.title: Submission for Develop: Prototype
attributes.body:
**Description:** This is a prototype for an app that assists families with scheduling and orchestrating meal planning meetings. It also aids the primary grocery shopper of the household in creating a list for their future shopping trip.

**Ritual:** My 'How Might We' statement is: How might we assist an indecisive individual, who is the primary grocery shopper of a household, with choosing what to make for dinners while planning their meals to shop for on an upcoming grocery store trip? The ritual I created to solve this issue is a weekly meal planning meeting among all members of a household. The first trigger would be the day of the week being the designated day of the week that the primary grocery shopper/family has chosen for their meeting. For example, say the designated day of the week is Saturday, on Saturday, the family would decide what time they wish to meet as a group. When the time of day reaches the proposed time for the meeting, all members agreed upon will meet in a predetermined area. In this room/area the meeting will be conducted. A timer should be set by the primary grocery shopper of the household for the estimated amount of time needed to thoroughly conduct the meeting. During this allotted time, the family will brainstorm together and share their ideas with the primary grocery shopper. Everyone is required to contribute, and while all ideas are welcomed, not every idea has to be used. By the time the meeting is done, more likely than not, either the timer will still have time on it or the timer will need reset with more time. This brainstorming time should be solely devoted to meal planning. After the meal plan has been created, it should be reviewed by all parties involved. Any changes or adjustments that need made to the meal plan should be done at this time. After reviewing the plan, each family member should confirm or deny that they are happy with the meal plan. Once each member has confirmed that they are happy with the proposed meal plan, all household members should thank one another for their time and should be released from the meeting. Following the meeting, the primary grocery shopper should review the meal plan and create a list accordingly so they are prepared for their next grocery trip.

**Prototype App:** The prototype app has multiple features and is viewed from the primary grocery shopper's prospective. Household members are not able to access all of the same features and may have different roles using the app than the primary grocery shopper. The first feature (in order of how they are presented on the home screen) is a feature allowing the primary grocery shopper the ability to invite members to their upcoming meal planning meeting. In this feature, the primary grocery shopper can add and remove members from receiving invites to the next meal planning meeting. The next feature is scheduling the meeting. Once members are invited, a time should be scheduled and sent among the invited members. Household members, on their end, can let the primary grocery shopper know either that the proposed time works for them or they can counter the request with a time that works better for them. Once the day and time has been agreed upon by all members, the members in the group will be notified with the official time and date. From there, the next feature is a timer. The timer is recommended to be used during the meeting. The primary grocery shopper should set the timer for their desired amount of time to conduct the meeting. The timer can be canceled at any time. The fourth feature is recipes available to view or uploading new ones. Both users, the primary grocery shopper and the household members, can view pre-uploaded recipes (under 'View Preexisting Recipes') or search for new pre-uploaded recipes (under 'Add New Recipes') or upload their own recipes (under 'Add New Recipes'). They can send them to other family members or save new recipes into their preexisting recipes folder for future reference. The fifth feature is creating a grocery list. This feature is meant for the primary grocery shopper. They can add in ingredients from preexisting recipes they have saved as well as add in items that are not listed in recipes. Once they save their list, can go back in later on and add in more items or even remove some. The last feature is the account settings. The individual's username will be listed, the password will be shown in stars, and the user's status (as a primary grocery shopper or a household member) will be shown. At any time users can revert to either the home screen or the side menu. Both pages offer the same links. 

**How it Supports the Ritual:** The app supports the ritual in numerous ways. The app allows the meeting to be scheduled among desired family members and for a time and date to be agreed upon by all members. When the time of the meeting arrives, the app will notify users about the upcoming meeting. Without the app, setting up the meeting would come down to individuals disagreeing on when the meeting was set for or even forgetting about the meeting in general. This way members are reminded about the meeting and can reference the scheduled time and date of when the meeting is. The app also supports the ritual by setting a timer for users so the party can be reminded that they need to solely dedicate x amount of time to meal planning. The timer will notify the primary grocery shopper when the allotted time is over and can be reset with more time if needed. The app also allows all family members to share recipes they may want included in the meal plan. Whether the recipes are used or not, they can always be saved for future reference. Having the ability to search recipes also allows users to find inspiration for meals if they are stuck or are indecisive. Lastly, the app helps the primary grocery shopper create their shopping list based off of the recipes they have preexisting. This could potentially save the primary grocery shopper precious time. Overall, the app and the ritual are meant to alleviate pressure from the primary grocery shopper who may typically undergo the meal planning process alone. Especially when they do not want the pressure of choosing everyone's meals on their own or they are indecisive. Having other's to lend a hand can be a huge relief and the app can be a tool to aid the primary grocery shopper that also provides ideas for meals.

attributes.title: Submission for Develop: Prototype
attributes.body: This is a prototype for an app that helps to carve out and create "me-time" during days that involve a lot of responsibilities or routines. This app will allow the user to create time for themselves when they want and how they want. On the home screen of the app, four options appear. Each option leads you to a different setting. The "Set Time" button takes you to a page to set the date and time for "me-time." You're intended to do this the night before, assuming you will know your schedule for the next day. By clicking on "Activities," you will be directed to choose the app's curated list of activities or your own list of activities. When you click on an activity, you will be asked if you're ready to begin. You can also always add more activities to your own list by clicking, "Add." The "Log" button on the home screen allows you to check how many times you've done each activity you have ever selected. The "Timer" selection on the home page takes you to a page where you can change the amount of time you want "me-time" to last. You can always go back and change the amount of time because some activities may take longer than others, or you may want to continue to engage in "me-time" for longer than you originally intended. (An important note: Clicking "Me-Time" at the top of the page will almost always bring you back to the home page. Think of it as a home button.) This app supports the ritual of "Me-Time" because it not only allows you to make time for it, it also gives you ideas and inspiration to be excited about creating time for yourself. It will give the user something to look forward to in their day, or if it's done early in the morning, it will start their day off right. Everyone deserves a little me-time.

attributes.title: Submission for Develop: Prototype
attributes.body:
This is a prototype for an app that is meant to help combat social anxiety. "be BRAVE." is meant to help take the anxiety out of social settings. No matter the person, or the situation, be BRAVE provides users with a way to help.
 
The ritual begins when anxiety strikes, which can be anywhere between getting cold feet about a situation, to sweating bullets in a crowded room of strangers. Opening the app, you are instantly reminded to be brave, a positive affirmation meant to set the mind at ease in a tense situation. The user is given a minimalistic interface so as not to add to any anxiety that may already be building up. The options provided give the user various ways to seek assistance in lowering their anxiety level.
 
The options available on the home screen are Inbox, Talk, and Discover. Starting with the center button, Talk, the user will enter into a screen with a list of available users online, along with a small thumbnail image for each user available. This is meant to be generalized across the entire be BRAVE. network or possibly have a setting to which could activate GPS and allow you to narrow your search to other users in your area. Once the user clicks a name, they are moved into a chat box that allows the user to message whom they clicked and begin a conversation.  Conversations held are meant to assist the user in being walked through various ways that could help dissolve their anxiety in their given situation. The idea behind be BRAVE is that all of the users have experienced, or currently experience social anxiety on some level, and sharing their experiences and what works for them could also help someone else.
 
Be BRAVE is meant to provide a comfortable environment while aiding in self-image and anxiety coping mechanisms among peers.
 
If the user, has already established relationships throughout the network, they can add friends, much like other social mediums, and remain in contact via Inbox messages through the application.
 
Knowing that sometimes, reaching out to someone or texting on your phone just might not be an option at the time, the Discover feature is meant to offer an alternative. Broken down into three sections (with room for more), this area of the application is meant to provide the user with different ways of coping. The breathing button would lead to various breathing exercises, as well as other meditative and even light physical exercises that could assist the user in coping.
 
Below that is a button labeled laugh, which may seem to explain itself. Some of those who have long lived with anxiety and know the tense feeling one can become overwhelmed within social settings, laughter or simply a smile can sometimes be the best answer. Laugh would provide the user with several different forms of entertainment meant to lighten the weight over their anxiety. This could be through small cartoons, popular memes, user-submitted jokes, and stories, as well as various other means.
 
Lastly, and sometimes most importantly, would be the button labeled positivity. This button would lead users into a section meant to tackle any areas of motivation. Social anxiety often has underlying reasoning, and the power of word can be an incredibly strong one. Here the user would find a series of links that could provide the user with outsourced information on well-being, self-image, positive affirmations, and perhaps even a forum based within the community that is meant to encourage each other without the time constraint of who is online and who isn't at the time.
 
These experiences allow the user to exhaust several means in not only helping themselves but also providing them the opportunity to help others, which in itself can improve someone's overall well-being and promote a more positive self-image.

attributes.title: Submission for Develop: Prototype
attributes.body:
# The Buddy System

This is a prototype for an app that connects people who share common life experiences and interests.  For many people, meeting and making new friends can be hard.  This app could bring people together and help them gain more pleasure from life.

**Background:** My Dad, at age 87, desires to make new friends.  Sadly, many of his dearest friends have passed away over the years and it's been difficult filling those losses.  Currently, he loves creating model gliders and takes them to the park for test flights all by himself.  With this app, he could be matched with people of similar interests and backgrounds.  Using its internal messaging capabilities, he could plan outings like flying gliders at the park.

**Idea:** The app would require a user to create a profile that would include information like location, occupation(s), hobbies, and activities.  Using an algorithm like ones used for matching couples, users will be alerted of a "buddy match".  Each user will be able to click on the potential buddy's profile and decide if they want to "Buddy Up" (accept) or "No Thanks" (decline) the match.  The potential buddy will do the same process and, if both parties agree to "Buddy Up", they are added to the user's buddy list.  If users already have friends using the app, they can perform a "Buddy Search" and perform the "Buddy Up" process that way.  

**Other Considerations:** Because there is an element of risk and anxiety connected with strangers, cautions of "Stranger Danger" and tips on making and keeping new friendships will be included.

attributes.title: Submission for Develop: Prototype
attributes.body:
This is a prototype for an app called "What's Next" that will lead to fulfilling activities for older and retired individuals looking for new pursuits. The ritual begins when the individual feels a sense of boredom or lack of purpose during the excess free time time that accompanies retirement. 

The ritual begins upon opening the app, when the user can access a list of friends and acquaintances with time to spare by navigating to the 'Connect' screen. Once there, the are able to see a list of who is available at that moment and can choose to contact them directly to arrange an activity or get-together. Clicking on the name "Jacqui" for example will take the user to a a member profile page in which they can message the person they wish to connect with. Included on this page is a list of past activities the user has spent done with the member if any. 

The next stage of the ritual begins if the user is unable to connect with someone they know personally. Now they can navigate to the "Search" screen. Here posts and events are extended to the community at large. Clicking on an event, for example "Birdwatching" takes the user to the event page in which they can contact the organizer or invite friends. The posts can come from individuals or local organizations and institutions.

They can also add the event to the 'My List' screen. This part of the app is meant to serve as a journal for the ritual. What interests the user? Who did they connect with? What would they like to try next? Circling back to the feeling of boredom that triggered the use of the app, the 'My List' feature can be used as a first point of reference to spark ideas,recall connections, and remind the user of enjoyable or not-so-enjoyable experiences. The goal here is to have a jumping off point to start trying new things. 

The What's Next app is meant to be an simple and easy to navigate experience that can aid older individuals in finding stimulating things to do with their time. By making connections and engaging with the community, this ritual gives them the ability to make use of their free time in new fulfilling ways.

attributes.title: Submission for Daily Design Journal: Report In
attributes.body:
**# Prompt**

**From the 14 objects that you sketched, which are your favorite objects? Why?**
My journal, as it's somewhere that I keep everything. Children's birthdays, classwork delegations, finances, and really a little bit of everything that I need in a day. My speaker because this is something that I use daily, and the quality performance has become a baseline standard in listening for me. Lastly, my candle and this is because of the pride I have in knowing that this is a product I made myself from the ingredients inside it to the design of the container. 

**Select one object from your list. What role does this object play in your life? What would be the result if you did not have it anymore?**
My journal, it serves more useful to me than even my phone in a tech-savvy world. I have it setup to remind me not just for daily tasks, but am able to use it for monthly, yearly, or maybe just weekly things. It's a place to keep all the important information I get in a day and have one solid place to look to for when I need to call on that information again. If I didn't have this anymore, I feel like I would be extremely unorganized. I would attempt to write things down in places and not remember where I put them, or what that jotted down note was even about. I would forget when bills were supposed to be paid, or when pieces of homework were due throughout the week. 

**Do you generally take these objects for granted or are they special?**
Most of these objects, I do treat as they are something special to me. Rexly my journal just because of it's everyday usage. The other objects I feel I may take for granted as my interactions with them might be slightly less, or at least less obvious. I wouldn't enjoy the way I listen to music as much if it weren't for my speaker, but I don't bother to think about 'What if it broke?' each time I'm hitting the power button. Certain things in our everyday life have become routine in that, and we forget the importance they hold in order for our routine to even exist.

Interview: 

Daily Challenge(s):
Not having time for myself to do what I want to do. 

-Wake up , pray, brush teeth, go to the gym, come home and drink shake, look at to do boards, try and accomplish a few things for work before my calls for the day, after all calls and work, I travel to the store and get food to cook for my family, we eat together, we spend time with our children, we put kids to bed at 9:30pm then hang out with my wife and then we go to bed. 

Do you find anything particularly challenging about your daily routine?
I have 2 jobs and many things to handle through out my day. Each day  I have to think through what are the most important things I have to focus on, in case I can't finish everything. Also seeing how I can delegate the other things if applicable. I want to focus on the things only I am able to do and let someone else do what I can not. 

    - Do you have any reoccurring frustrations?
    - Being contacted with "very important things" out of no where from people that I work with or family. Usually is very distracting and it takes me off task. 

    - If you could change something about your typical day, what would it be?
    - I would wake up earlier. Have energy all day long and have a personal assistant that I can delegate things to. 
    - Being able to fall asleep. I struggle with falling asleep at night which doesn't allow me to wake up earlier than I would like.

Is there something that, if only you were incredibly good at it, you could improve some aspect of your life?
Falling asleep so that I am able to wake up earlier would greatly improve my life. 

Why aren't you good at it? ("it" should be a specific thing, see Laddering - Five 'Why?'s) 
Insomnia, 

What do you value more: stability 

Why do you think that is? ("it" should be a specific thing, see Laddering - Five 'Why?'s : Because I was raised with people who did not know how to manage their money and always have money problems and I don't want that for my life. I also tend to live my life as prudent as possible. 

What is a place that has special meaning to you? (At home, or elsewhere)
The bathroom (my place to get away from the family and have peace to myself)

What details can you recall most clearly? Describe them.
Not sure what this means.

What is a group, culture, or "tribe" that you strongly identify with?
Christianity, woke black people, woke multi cultural people and woke christians 

How do your participate in, or show your connection to, that group?
Lead a life group/bible study every Sunday and Im black everyday 

Prepare three or more original questions that you will ask your subject.

1. If you could help people that don't understand the way you feel about Christianity, name one thing you would do? Hear them out 
2. You've become successful in life and came from an environment of poverty, how could you help others through technology to do the same? You can't make people want something. They have to want it for themselves. You can use technology as a form of advertising to show them there's a better form of life out there. 
3. What is something you would like to achieve that you haven't already in life? Successfully launching a software business
